trial_identification.scientifictitle: Tai Chi for independent living: RCT of efficacy of Tai Chi in delaying disability among older people

interventions.interventions:
Study intervention: Focus and Flow Exercise Program (Tai Chi for Arthritis Part I-12 basic moves and Part II-reverse of the 12 basic moves plus additional 9 advanced moves)
Both exercise programs are delivered in group settings, 1 hour sessions twice weekly, for 48 weeks, by trained instructors
interventions.comparator: Control intervention: Flex and Bend Exercise Program (stretching and relaxation exercises)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Physical functioning and disability measured with the Late Life Function and Disability Instrument
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 48 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Joint pain, stiffness and function measured with the WOMAC Osteoarthritis Index
Cardiac function measured by heart rate and blood pressure
Static balance measured by postural sway and single leg stance
Dynamic balance measured by the Step Test, Timed up and Go test, and two elements from Berg Balance Scale

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured prospectively for 48 weeks using a falls calendar.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Fear of falling measured using the modified Tinetti falls efficacy scale
Concentration and memory measured with the Digit Cancellation and California Verbal Learning Tests
Life satisfaction using the Life Satisfaction Index
Depression using he Beck Depression Inventory
Quality of life using the Assessment of Quality of Life instruement
Health services use using data from the Health Insurance Commission, Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and Department of Veteran Affairs
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: For the period from 12 months prior to the intevention through to 12 months after the intervention

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Living in community (including retirement villages)preclinical stage of disability based on measure developed by Fried (J Clin Epi, 2001; 54:889-901
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Already participating in Tai Chimoderate cognitive impairmentmajor unstable cariod-pulmonary diseaseterminal cancer or other life threatening illnessmajor psychiatric illnessdo not have approval from general practitioner.

trial_design.sequence: computerised sequence generation stratified by retirement village at which classes held, and by type of residence (retirement village or own home)
trial_design.designfeatures: Assessors will be blinded to group allocation. Subjects and exercise program leaders will be blinded to true hypothesis as they will be told the aim of the trial is to compare two different exercise programs

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study addresses the issue of disability among our ageing population. Preservation of function among our older citizens, and their capacity to live independently, is of significant social, public health and economic benefit. The aims of this study are to (1) test the efficacy of Tai Chi in delaying disability among older people, prior to its onset, (2) investigate the mechanisms by which Tai Chi intervenes in the disability pathway, (3) determine the cost-benefits of Tai Chi for older people. The study will recruit 500 people over 70 years of age and randomly assign them to receive either Tai Chi, or a stretching and relaxation program, for a period of 48 weeks. The groups will then be compared to determine if there is any difference in the development of disability as well as a range of functional outcomes such as strength, balance, depression, arthritic symptoms, life satisfaction, and falls.
